unit: Unit 7 | Inference for Quantitative Data: Means
title: Cereal Boxes
question_text:
A spokesman for a large cereal company is interested in whether a new promotion of including a toy in every box of cereal would greatly increase sales.
He figures that age would be a factor, so he selects one pair of subjects at each age range from $10$ to $79$ by increments of $5\text{ years}$.
The spokesman flips a coin to decide which of the pair gets a coupon for a free prize every time they buy a box of the cereal. After one year, each subject is asked how many boxes of that brand of cereal they bought.
The data is in the table below (scroll right to see full table):
From this data, is there convincing statistical evidence that people buy more cereal when a prize coupon is included?
tables:
Age Range10- 1415- 1920- 2424- 2930- 3435- 3940- 4445- 4950- 5455- 5960- 6465- 6970- 7475-79
With Coupon98854121413865442
Without Coupon74865787664341

choices.text: Yes, at the $1\%$, $5\%$, and $10\%$ alpha levels.
Yes, at the $5\%$ and $10\%$ alpha level, but not the $1\%$ level.
Yes, at the $10\%$ alpha level, but not the $5\%$ or $1\%$ levels.
No, not at none of the common alpha levels of $1\%$, $5\%$, or $10\%$.
Yes, since the mean of the “with prize” is above the mean of the “without prize.”
